title: a levels results day wales twins off oxford university
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe girls, who are students at Cardf Sixth Form College and before that went to Stanwell School, have however chosen very dferent courses to study.Arianne who gained A* in French, A* in Politics, A* in History and A* in Biology is off to study Law with French Law at Mansfield College and Enyala who gained A* in Maths, A* in Physics, A* in Chemistry and A* in History has a place to study Materials Science at Queenrsquos College.As well as top academic students, Arianne has been part of the Welsh Debating Team and travelled to India and Thailand last year to represent Wales in the World Schools Debating Championships.Enyala won a Gold Crest Award in the Engineering Education Scheme Wales, played the leading role of Kenickie in the school production of Grease and is a keen pianist.Both girls are also members of Welsh National Youth Opera.After collecting her grades this morning, Arianne said: ldquoIrsquom so happy. I am so interested in how the legal world is changing and in particular looking at which laws we maintain and which we change coming out of the EU.ldquoCoupling law with French means that I can look at the international side of law and I am very much looking forward to learning more about both the British and French legal systems.ldquoIt is also very attractive to me to think about what the law should be from a moral perspective rather than just its application.Enyala by contrast was less sure of the direction she was going to take until she attended an Oxbridge conference in Swansea.ldquoThis was the first time I was introduced to material science she said. ldquoI really liked the structure of Oxfordrsquos course and the mixture of physics, chemistry and maths in the subject ndash it is very broad and follows on well from my EQP in nuclear energy.Both girls joined top school Cardf Sixth Form College on a  per cent scholarship from their local state school where they achieved  A*s each at GCSE.ldquoChanging schools has been a really good preparation for university le, Enyala said.ldquoIt has certainly made me more independent and aware of the world. When I joined Cardf Sixth Form I signed up for everything and particularly enjoyed playing music with some exceptionally talented musicians, taking part in badminton tournaments and performing in the drama productions.ldquoFor the first time Arianne and I have made separate friends, perhaps because we chose such dferent subjects.ldquoAs twins this is quite unusual as we are very alike in many ways but also have very dferent sides to our personalities.Arianne added: ldquoThe people were the best part of my school experience and everyone was really willing to learn and it was very easy to make friends. I felt welcome very quickly and the teachers were really inspiring. We are used to answering to each otherrsquos names so it was refreshing to actually have our own space and to realise that as well as being similar we also had room to develop very dferent talents.       ,params: .pushThe girls have also been busy during lockdown where they recorded a song and have learnt how to cook in readiness for university. Enyala has been teaching herself the guitar and Arianne has started to learn Spanish.Principal of Cardf Sixth Form College, Gareth Collier said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted that Enyala and Arianne have achieved places at Oxford as they will add so much to the community.ldquoBoth the girls have really inputted into le here at Cardf Sixth Form College with Arianne developing her leadership skills as a prefect and Enyala bringing a real sense of humour into her science lessons.ldquoI am very much looking forward to seeing how they develop and will certainly be inviting them back to share their experiences, which no doubt will be very dferent, with future students at the school. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log        ,params: .push-- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: welsh government allows families meet reveals new premises enforcement powers
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. from Saturday, August  up to four households will be able to join together to form a single extended household.A meal following a wedding, civil partnership or funeral will be allowed for up to  people indoorssocial distancing can be maintained.However, the Welsh Government will not be making any changes to the rules on people meeting indoors with people who arenrsquot part of their household or extended household.MORE STORIESFirst minister to set out changes to coronavirus regulations in WalesSouth Wales buildings and venues light up red to highlight industry now on Red AlertWelsh Government unveils support package to keep people in their homes and end homelessnessThis means that people should only visit pubs, restaurants, or other places indoors with people from their household or extended household.Amendments to the regulations will also come into force next week to make it obligatory for hospitality businesses and other high-risk settings to collect contact details of customers.Collecting this information is essential for Walesrsquo test trace protect strategy for testing the general public and preventing the spread of coronavirus.Placing this in the regulations will make it clear to managers of premises and to customers that collecting information of this sort is a requirement, not an option.Mr Drakeford said: ldquoWales has come together to tackle the spread of this virus and the action we have taken together has made a real dference."The number of cases continue to fall and this means we will be able introduce new changes to allow up to four households to come together and form an extended household.ldquoThese are cautious, step by step changes."We are learning from what is happening across the UK and outbreaks are mainly linked to people meeting others inside the home."That is why it is so important we donrsquot invite people outside our extended households into our homes."We have made so much progress and we mustnrsquot jeopardise this."That means we are not at a point where we should be visiting anyonersquos home at any time."Regulations on meeting outdoors were recently changed to make it easier to do, and this remains by far the safest way to meet.ldquoThere are also indications from other parts of the UK where pubs opened earlier than Wales that outbreaks have been linked to those places."If we are to avoid introducing local lockdown measures that could require the whole sector to close, it is vital we can quickly respond to any outbreaks.       ,params: .push"Providing our contact details when attending these premises will mean people can be contacted quickly by our Test Trace Protect teamsthey may have been exposed to coronavirus.ldquoOnly by us all doing our part and taking personal responsibility for our actions can we continue to tackle the scourge of coronavirus.ldquoFor iniduals, this means keeping a two metre distance from others, washing our hands often and wearing a face covering on public transport."For businesses this means taking action to protect customers, including taking their contact details so we can identy any outbreaks."While many businesses are being careful to collect contact details, there are too many reports of this not happening."As a result, we will be bringing in new regulations next week to make this compulsory.ldquoThis pandemic is far from over and we all still have a duty to do our part to keep Wales safe.The Welsh Government recently strengthened the powers local authorities have to enforce the regulations.This enables enforcement officers to issue a Premises Improvement Notice to highlight breaches and specy measures that need be taken on premises to comply with the law.Where a Premises Improvement Notice is not Others built roads and bridges."TheBurma-Thailand railway was nicknamed, lsquoDeath Railwayrsquo, after , prisoners of war and , local labourers died constructing its path."The allied civilians living in the Far East were captured and interned in camps, where women, children and men were subjected to similarly brutal conditions."For all those who survived ndash military and civilians - the wounds of war were etched firmly in their psyche for good."After the joy of Victory in Europeday, we can only imagine the courage and fortitude of those who remained at war for another three long months."The Welsh troops serving in the Far East and Pacic faced conditions theyrsquod never even heard of before."In extreme heat, in monsoons, alongside mosquitos and facing tropical disease, their battle was quite extraordinary."Collaboration with allies was key to success. Indian, Myanmarese, Nepali and troops from across the African continent, led the effort in South East Asia with Australian, New Zealand, Pacic Islanders, US and Canadians in the South West and Central Pacic."Many other nations also contributed."Around  per cent of personnel of the main army in South East Asia ndash the th Army - hailed from modern day India, Pakistan and Bangladesh."The contribution of volunteers across the nations was staggering. The Indian Army, had grown to . million members by the end of the war, making it the largest volunteer army in history."After the elation of VE day, some Welsh troops who survived the Far East felt like the lsquoForgotten Armyrsquo."They had served so far away, cut off from their loved ones and any contact with the world they had known."The focus at home had firmly been on Europe they could be forgiven for thinking their efforts had been forgotten."Tragically, many who died were left in those foreign fields, in unmarked graves."On Victory in Japanday, those in the Far East were still overseas, or on board a ship in the middle of the ocean like Stan Smith from Barry, weeks or months from home."Those who ed were changed forever by their experiences."He added: "On Saturday, we will multi-storey car park on the existing Old Harbour site.Their call follows residents continuing to see visitors parking in streets outside their homes in addition to the knowledge that once the former Butlins Nellrsquos Point site, parking capacity would be reduced.Baruc ward councillor, Steffan Wiliam first suggested the idea in response to parking concerns.He said the Island needs to be lsquofuture-proofedrsquo to cater for increased tourist numbers and ensure minimal disruption for Island residents.MORE STORIESBarry Island residents want to reclaim streets from motorists avoiding cafeacute owner, Dave Lewis said: ldquoBarry Island has a car parking problem because over the years the number of spaces have diminished and ndash with the councilrsquos plan to sell land where the Nellrsquos Point car park at the moment ndash the situation will only get worse.ldquoThatrsquos a great pity because Barry Island is such a fantastic location and - whilst there is a railway and buses ndash people come from further afield and do need parking.ldquoAt the moment we have visitors who overflow into the rest of the Island into the residential areas.ldquoAs well as being a cafeacute owner Irsquom a resident and I can see the problems.ldquoSomething needs to happen at some point to allow Barry Island to continue to grow.ldquoThe proposal for a multi-storey car park is a really good idea.ldquoWhatever is proposed and built is something that fits around Barry Island.ldquoWe donrsquot want an eyesore ndash the first thing that people see is some ugly monstrosity of a car park.ldquoIt would be really goodthere was some sort of multi-purpose construction.ldquoWhatever goes there needs to have some sort of validity as a building as well as a car park.ldquoWhatever is developed needs to provide good value, structured car parking prices.ldquoMost traders on Barry Island would say what wersquove got on Barry Island doesnrsquot really work.ldquoA pound for an hour and pound for the whole of the day and nothing in between.ldquoThis has been raised a number of times with the council, but it falls on deaf ears.ldquoThey are quite happy for visitors to be paying pound, but you canrsquot always walk from the car park for a coffee within an hour.ldquoThis is why car parking is a problem ndash because the charges are unfair.ldquoSomething needs to be done.Marco Zeraschi, of Marcorsquos Cafeacute, said: ldquoIrsquove always been an advocate of a multi-storey car park on Harbour Road.ldquoJust donrsquot put a brick building up or something sterile.ldquoDress it to make it look like a ship or a sail or something like that which would blend in with the seaside.ldquoDress it so it doesnrsquot look like an eyesore from outside the Island as well ndash it could be something special there, iconic.ldquoYou could do wonderful things with some good imagination.ldquoThe Nellrsquos Point car park is still up for development andwe lose that yoursquove lost over  car parking spaces.ldquoWe need an extra  never mind .ldquoIf you multi-storey the Harbour Road one there would be a vast improvement and you would have control over it to stop the boy racers at night.ldquoAnd it would make money for the Valethey had , spaces.He added: ldquoIf residents think theyrsquove got it bad now, the residents of the West End of Barry will have it as well.Vale town and Barry Town Council Baruc ward councillors, Nic Hodges and Steffan Wiliam reiterated their call for a multi-storey car park on the Old Harbour site.Cllr Hodges said: ldquoWith the increasing popularity But we have to go much furtherwe are serious about developing the economy of the island, whilst also ensuring a decent quality of le for residents.Both councillors, acknowledging the need to further promote more environmentally-friendly methods of getting to and from the Island such as public transport, walking, and cycling, said it must be recognised that families will continue to bring cars containing their beach equipment.ldquoIgnoring that fact isnrsquot an option, said Island resident and councillor, Steffan Wiliam, who first proposed the combination of resident parking and a multi-storey car park.Cllr Wiliam said: ldquoWe realised that we must future-proof the island so that it could sustain the welcome growth in visitor numbers, but also to prevent the unnecessary and unacceptable nuisance and anti-social behaviour that residents have had to put up with.ldquoThis is an opportunity to create something beautul but al with materials that complement the existing landscape, based on a maritime theme perhaps. landlords and councils.The investment package will lead to better homes, help tackle fuel poverty and contribute to decarbonisation.MORE STORIESWelsh ministers unveil multi-million pound support WalesMinister for housing and local government, Julie James launched the Optimised Retrofit Programme during a visit to Craig Cefn Parc in Swansea.The ORP will support the sector to test dferent approaches to reach the goal of carbon neutrality.It will include an innovation competition - opening next month - to support the piloting of innovative new solutions for retrofitting housing stock.The knowledge and learning gained will influence the future of the Welsh Housing Quality Standard so that all those living in social homes will benefit from reduced energy bills and warmer, more efficient homes.ORP is a key part of the poundm Innovative Housing Programme announced earlier this year, which focuses on building new carbon neutral homes using modern methods of construction, the scheme will contribute to plans to reduce greenhouse gases by  per cent by  with an ambition to reach net zero in future.Applications for the Innovative Housing Programmersquos fourth year are now officially open.A collaboration across Welsh Government, the programme has been part funded through the innovation and business streams.It has long been recognised that retrofitting homes will be a key tool in the green economic recovery, with the ambition the programme will create jobs, provide training and skills in both existing and new retrofit and heating technology.It is hoped technologies and skills created through the programme can be rolled out across wider private sector homes, ensuring Walesrsquo place as lsquofirst mover regionrsquo for decarbonisation of homes by reducing carbon emissions from around , social and fuel poor homes.Ms James said: ldquoThe coronavirus pandemic has highlighted the importance of a warm, secure and affordable home like never before."It has also shown the positive effects of reducing greenhouse gasses.ldquoHousing is responsible for  per cent of all energy consumed in Wales and  per cent of all demand side greenhouse gas emissions.While we have plans in place to ensure new homes are heated and powered only from clean energy sources, ensuring our existing housing stock is as energy efficient as possible is vital towe are to meet our ambitious target of reducing our greenhouse gas emissions by  per cent by .This scheme is essential to tackling climate change, and driving down household energy costs now and in the future.Helping people, including those on lower incomes, to reduce their fuel bills while keeping their homes warm.Economy minister, Ken Skates said: ldquoA welcome boost to the Welsh economy, retrofitting homes will provide quality jobs and training opportunities in the heart of our communities."To help drive forward innovation and build a Welsh supply chain we will be launching a competition for social landlords to apply for research and innovation funding in September.Deputy chief executive and director of policy and external affairs at Community Housing Cymru, Clarissa Corbisiero said: ldquoDespite the immediate threat of covid-, the climate emergency has not gone away, and the pandemic has only highlighted the need for more good quality, affordable homes."Housing associations in Wales are committed to playing their part in tackling these issues."We now have an opportunity to learn from the experiences of the last few months, and be ambitious in our response."This funding is a welcome first step to decarbonise , homes, build local supply chains and create jobs in our communities. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net title: outdoor events trialled wales easing lockdown
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe trials are part of further changes to coronavirus regulations announced by first minister, Mark Drakeford.Indoor visits to care homes will also be allowed from Saturday, August , subject to the strict controls set out in the guidance and conditions remaining favourable.However, the first minister emphasised that theof pupils to schools and colleges from September  is the top priority during this  day regulation cycle.The Welsh Government recognises the value of the events sector to Wales and how cultural, sports and business events are a vital part of the visitor economy and one of the last sectors left to re-open.Initially three small events, with limits of up to  people, and subject to strict risk assessments, will be held across Wales later this month.Outdoor events are being prioritised in this review period, while the weather is mild, due to evidence of lower transmission of coronavirus outdoors.If these small events can be carried out safely, and transmission of the virus remains low, it is hoped the next stage will be increased numbers of participants, allowing a limited number of spectators to attend sporting events and potentially considering trialling small scale business events.In the coming weeks three small scale events will be trialled to inform future review processes.Outdoor events of up to  people include Theatr Clwydrsquos proposals for a number of live outdoor performances from August,  Welsh Triathlonrsquos planned lsquoReturn to Racingrsquo competition at Pembrey Country Park which will be a closed venue and without spectators and a car rally at Anglesey Circuit Trac Mon Race track.The Welsh Government continues to work closely with the UK Government to monitor the outcomes from the trials that have taken place recently.Mr Drakeford also confirmed that from Saturday, August , extended households can expand to include up to four households in an exclusive, extended arrangement.From the same day, weddings and funerals will be able to include a meal for up to  people, in suitably socially distant settings.Subject to the successful resumption of weddings and funerals, it is hoped to further increase the range of indoor ceremonies allowed in the next review period, including christenings, baptisms and bar mitzvahs.Casinos will be allowed to reopen from Saturday, August , provided they follow the guidance available to them.Mr Drakeford said: ldquoWhile coronavirus remains effectively suppressed in Wales and cases continue to fall, the situation in the rest of the UK and further afield is still problematic."Coronavirus has not gone away and so, as we move out of lockdown and look to the future, it is important we do this in a careful and cautious way.ldquoWe appreciate how hard it has been for families not seeing their loved ones and the impact restrictions on visiting care homes is having on peoplersquos emotional, mental and even physical health.ldquoIn an effort to address this we have been working closely with partners and intend to allow indoor visits to care homes to recommence from Saturday, August , subject to the strict controls set out in the guidance and conditions remaining favourable.ldquoIn addition we will trial three small scale events, in partnership with the events organisers, local authorities and other stakeholders, to seethey can be carried out in a safe way, with a view to supporting the sector and making the most of the remaining summer months where we can spend time outdoors.ldquoWe will also learn from pilots being conducted across the UK, in reopening professional sport and indoor theatre to supporters and audiences, so we base our decisions on the best possible evidence available."We will continue to talk with event organisers about the possible resumption of some other activities later in the autumn.ldquoBut, for the time being, we need to learn from how we can safely hold outdoor events while maintaining social distancing.ldquoWe will use the next three weeks to continue to engage with those remaining sectors of our economy that remain affected by coronavirus restrictions."I would like to thank the sector representatives for the way they continue to engage, coming out of lockdown will always be harder than going into it - but, together, we will do it in the safest possible way.From  September, schools and further education colleges willfrom the summer break, and will teach pupils through a iety of ways, either in the classroom or remotely.The First Minister added:ldquoTheof pupils is the most signicant important activity which will take place in Wales during the next  days and most of the headroom we have is being devoted to making this a success.ldquoIt is critical that we get children back into schools in the safest possible way. All children in Wales have had the opportunity to lsquocheck in, catch up and preparersquo before the summer holidays, and we hope this will stand them in good stead for the changes they are due to encounter in the upcoming months. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. event with Manchester Libraries on September, .Ms Pearse said: ldquoI am so thrilled to be asked to launch #LibrariesFromHomeLIVE."Libraries have always held a special place in my heart."As a child they were escape from a harsh home le, a place I could soak up tales of adventure, transport myself to lands across the world and imagine being anyone I wanted to be."Now with this virtual series, readers will be able to meet writers they love in their own homes talking about their craft, and discover other writers they may not be so familiar with while finding new exciting books to read."For us authors it is a wonderful way to travel the country and like Rupert Bear, my favourite as a small child, to lsquoStill be Home in Time for Tearsquo.Chief executive, Libraries Connected, Isobel Hunter said: ldquoWe are delighted to be offering this wonderful opportunity for local public library communities to meet a much loved and much borrowed author."Whilst libraries are gradually re-opening services physically, it is brilliant that they are able to continue to inspire their communities to read through their digital offers."It is very exciting for us to be offering this tour and to be working with Lesley who is such a passionate library supporter and we canrsquot wait for the first event.For information, visit www.librariesconnected.org.ukGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: Car destroyed in arson attackMissing person - Gordie WalkerNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsVJ Day event welcomed by DUP and SFArmagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon Borough Council’s event to celebrate the th anniversary of VJ Day has been welcomed by both the DUP and Sinn Fein.By The NewsroomThursday, th August , : pm""Council has confirmed a shared history event to mark the occasion will take place this Saturday, August .Many local people were heldas Japanese prisoners of war and the stories of their experience still haunt the families to this day.The event will include a lecture from renowned historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, poetry reading by local historian Richard Edgar and a musical accompaniment from piper Ian Burrows.Speaking about the event, Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage said: “Shared history events are important for a ided society.“We hope that by embracing social media and digital technology we can attract wider audiences comprised of people who – for ious reasons – might not normally attend such an event in person.“With COVID- still very much a concern at the moment, we are hoping to run more online events like these to ensure we’re minimising the risk to our residents while still offering the excellent events we’re known for, albeit in a slightly dferent way.”DUP group whip Councillor Darryn Causby said it was important for Council to mark the occasion, widely regarded as the end of the second World War.“It is important for Council to mark this occasion,” he said.“We are obviously disappointed that it could not be marked in a more substantial way than what we are doing.“However, we welcome the fact all parties recognise the vital role the British Army played during the second World War and we welcome that across the piece.”Speaking about ABC Council’s shared history event SinnFein group leader, Councillor Liam Mackle said: “Many local people lost their lives in this conflict.“The Lord Mayor will pay special tribute to local man Jim Haughey. Jim fought against fascismin the International Brigade in the Spanish Civil War and was later killed in .“Council officers deserve special praise for organising this event which was inclusive and contributed to our shared understanding of history.”Initially proposed by DUP group leader, Councillor Mark Baxter duringthe course of July’s full council meeting, the idea to hold a socially distanced event compliant with COVID regulations was put to a vote following a fiery debate.In total,  members voted for the proposal with the DUP, UUP, Alliance Party and IndependentCouncillorPaul Berry in support of the proposal.The five SDLP members present abstained and the nine Sinn Fein members present voted against the proposal.The event will be broadcast on Council’s facebook page from -.am on Saturday, August .
